author: GBarrington
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2024
content: I'm experimenting with replacing my Windows PC with a higher end tablet.  so I wanted a docking station  (let's call it the DS) to connect it to a mouse, keyboard, and most i importantly, my 28 inch display screen.  So Far, So Good!  This review is going through the docking station, the S9, and DEX, then displayed on a nice big screen!  I REALLY like using a REAL keyboard!Once it was delivered, I rushed to my workstation to see how it worked.  And it didn't!  Nothing, NOTHING would work.  It kept telling me to check the cables.  So out of frustration, I had lunch.It turned out that the case I bought for the S9 fooled me into thinking I had the DS plugged into the tablet, but it was not.  Once I had figured THAT out, the docking station, and the tablet worked well together.I like that I'm using two different RF Dongles for the keyboard and mouse plugged into the DS.  I don't have to use battery power to use Bluetooth for those accessories.  Plus, I still have one USB 3.0 port free.  The Keyboard and Mouse don't appear to lag, at all.  If it does, it is so minor that I am unable to percieve it.I like that I can power the Tablet from the DS.  I'm using a 20 watt Amazon charger, and it seems to work just fine.  The tablet doesn't give me any messages that I'm on a slow charge and it seems to charge as it does without the DS.The only real negative is that the cable from the DS to the Tab S9 is a bit too short for the tablet to be propped upright.  The tablet display remains on, and the S Pen can be used with it.  I'm thinking that I might want to use the tablet itself as a sort of touchpad sometimes.  I might find applications where I would want the tablet display to remain upright.  I don't know, but it MIGHT be a problem, maybe.Build quality seems good.  I think the DS case is metal, at least it looks and feels like aluminum.  And the cord going to the Tablet seems quite robust.  I can't comment yet on reliabiy,  It will take some time for that info to appear.  But functionally, it is everything the seller claims it is.  I am satisfied.

author: Randall R. Brachmann
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2024
content: I needed a powered port expander for my DELL laptop.  I was having issues with data/communication to my printer and I read that a powered port extender would solve this.  This is the right tool for the job with a few caveats.  The multi-port is solid and well built and lightweight for travel.  My new DELL Inspiron 16 uses a smart power adapter.  The system must have a minimum of 65 watts to boot up.  When I attach the power adapter to the muli-port and then the multi-port to the laptop, get a message about a weak charge (see attached photo).  Working with the vendor and their support team, we tried several options.  They even sent me a 2nd unit at no added charge.  Sadly, the problem was still showing.  I suspect the smart power adaptor is sensing the draw of the multi-port regardless of the laptop and stepping down to a lower wattage.  Ultimately, I connected the power adapter directly to the laptop and then used a spare power adapter just for the multi-port.  My laptop now reboots properly and I have the powered multi-port I needed to support an additional display (HDMI), HP Desk Jet (USB 3.0), I-Book (standalone hard drive), a spare USB 3.0 port for thumb drive, and a port for my original non-powered 4-port USB extender which I still use for my free-standing keyboard, and my laptop vent (fan) system.  The USB-C cable used to connect the multi-port to the laptop is about 5 inches long, so I had some rearranging to make this spaghetti mess to workout.  I'm told it's to minimize data loss/corruption to drives, monitors, etc.  Everything now works great.The support team was very helpful and patient.  Never condescending or argumentative.  They responded to my original review the next day and offered a refund or a new device while we worked on the problem.  I kept the device and didn't seek a refund.  I'm very happy with them.  Do I wish it worked with the laptop adapter instead of a 2nd adapter?  Sure, but I don't see this as their problem but something with the DELL.

author: Tech Tango
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2018
content: This adapter packs a lot of features into a small 12cm device, and is perfectly usable as a portable "mini-Dock".Linux?  Windows 10?  Android?  Yes!The design is a sleek metal case, seamless, with no visible screws.Slender, with no parts to lose, takes up very little space in the bag -- about as much as two Sharpie pens.It has a captive 6-inch cable with USB-C, and connections for USB-C PD, HDMI, Ethernet, and three USB 3.0 (blue) sockets.  Inside is a USB Hub, Ethernet Adapter, and HDMI display (&audio) output.The HDMI output is driven by your computer's internal graphics adapter, so the second monitor is integrated into both Windows and Linux with no additional drivers.  I believe it's done with a Via Labs VL100 "Billboard" Display Alternate mode adapter for USB-C, so it adds a second Monitor/Display instance, but not a new Display Adapter.The USB xHCI hub (VIA Labs 2109:0817 VL812 Super Speed Hub) appears on the bus, and this provides the three open USB ports as well as the new Ethernet Controller.  It's a Realtek USB GbE Family Controller:  VID: 0bda and PID: 8153.  Drivers were automatically available in both Ubuntu Linux and Windows 10.  It linked up to a 1Gb Ethernet as normal, no prompts or settings needed.For the adventurous, this UtechSmart device also works with the Samsung Galaxy S9+, and surprisingly well!Plug a USB Thumbdrive into the ports and it appears as a Storage Device, perfect for copying pictures off the phone.The Ethernet works as well, and automatically gets a DHCP address and switches over to wired connection.The HDMI monitor shows a clone of the Galaxy S9+ screen in perfect detail.  Best to rotate the phone to horizontal to make the most of the monitor.  (Sorry, no Samsung Dex environment here, but a USB Mouse and Keyboard work just fine.)Powering the adapter also charges the phone, as expected, but not as fast as a direct connection.  I was more impressed that the phone happily powered the whole adapter, with HDMI, Ethernet, and USB from its own battery, no problem.I was going to poke fun at the whole Phone + Adapter + Monitor, Ethernet, USB Drive, Keyboard, Mouse, but now that it's been running for a while on my desk, I'm imagining it could be useful if you intend to be at your phone for hours, hammering out email or Amazon reviews.All in all, this is a really nice piece of kit to have in your travel bag, or as a single-connection desktop dock.  It has replaced my USB-On-The-Go (OTG) adapters, as those were always a bit sketchy with some USB devices, and prevented charging..  Even if I don't need all the features, it's small enough on the bag that it's replaced a number of other adapters already.I accepted an offer to test and review this device, and received it for free, but this is my honest and unbiased review.  Pictures are my own.

content: This seems like a very attractive and useful product, but it just did not last for me.  I bought it in August 2021 and used it daily for an ethernet connection with intermittent use as a USB hub.  Within 6 months I started to have mysterious connectivity issues, but for some reason always found a way to blame my internet provider somehow.  But then the dropped Zoom calls got to be just too much and I decided to go through my whole system replacing one part at a time. My problem was cured (and remains cured for 2 months) after replacing the first connection in the sequence - this device.  It also used to get very warm when in use, and I have the impression that it got warmer when any USB plug was used and that was associated with more ethernet failure. USB functionality was also a little weird and selective - things like keyboards worked fine, camera memory card readers very selective.

content: This was a frustrating product. Tried using as the central component (hub if you will) of my Macbook Pro desktop setup. From the initial usage it was flaky, requiring multiple plug/un-plug cycles to get everything to work at the same time. 2/3 times the video would not work, maybe 1/4 times the USB would not work. Ended up taking an average of 4 or 5 times to plug in and remove to get everything working. Then after several months of this the power pass-through stopped working. I found out when I walked up to my device I had left plugged in and the battery was dead. Now it sort of works when I power through the other USB port but not when I try to pass power through. A few weeks after this the laptop's USB ports failed, I can't say what caused it of course but reading other reviews who also had their ports fail it does make me wonder. I replaced the laptop, now I guess I'll try again to get a working docking station but won't trust this brand again!

content: If you're hoping to add some extras to a new Dell laptop, you may want to take a look at what's compatible. Dell doesn't allow 3rd party hardware to preform PD, you may use a 3rd party USB-C charger of appropriate wattage directly but geniuses at Dell restrict Power delivery unless the thunderbolt port detects Dell OEM parts.I bought a 95w USB-C Charger to connect Power Delievery through 3 seperate USB-C port(usb3.0)/rj45/HDMI devices that all claim to have Battery PD (including this one), but the Battery keeps saying the charger is slow. over hours the battery will trickly down to about 95% before I plug it back into the OEM charger it came with. author: Harald Hardrada
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 19, 2022
content: If you only plug this device in at night to charge, it will probably last 2+ years and serve you well. If you use it like a docking station, i.e. connecting and disconnecting as you come and go from the office, it will wear out much faster.  Mine started to have difficulty connecting to my phone after 6 months, and at one year I have to plug it in several times to get it to connect. It also drops the connection at random.The other weakness it's had from day one is that the gigbit ethernet interface takes a lot of power. When using it to browse, the time it takes to charge from 15% increases from 2-3 hours to 10-30 hours (even with the factory charger that supports USB Power Delivery). Heavy use will drain the battery even when it's plugged in.Neither of these problems are the fault of the manufacturer or their engineers. USB-C just isn't as tough as USB-A or the ports on a good quality laptop docking station. And most gigabit ethernet devices consume much more power than their 10/100 predecessors.If those are acceptable limitations, then by all means by this product. It's as well-made as it could be given the limitations of the industry standards.

author: Qbert888
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 3, 2022
content: I was looking for an USB C Ethernet adapter for my new Samsung Galaxy book 2 Pro 360, and the first couple I ordered had the problem of constantly disconnecting and reconnecting. After some digging into the issue, it seems this has been a common problem the plagues USB C adapters, and may be due to the connection being loose, or the hub overheating, and the hub not being able to supply all the power necessary to maintain connection. So I needed a hub that had PD so that power draw would always be sufficient to maintain connection. This hub has worked as advertised, It hasn't disconnected once, and I have plugged 3 external hard drives, in addition to the Ethernet port, and getting very fast speeds, well over 400 Mbps on my 400 Mbps plan, and upload speeds are as advertised as well. So far I am very happy with the purchase, I will update this review once I have used the HDMI port.Update: 7.15.22My laptop no longer recognizes the USB Hub. I contacted customer service to request a warranty replacement, and they shipped one out within a couple days. After sthinking about why the first hub failed, I believe it could be a heat issue. I have 3 external USB SSDs connected to the hub along with the Ethernet port, and the USB C power delivery port to provide the necessary power. I notice it gets quite warm, so I have been monitoring the heat, and placing it on a cooling pad, which keeps it from getting too hot. I wish I didn't have to use the cooling pad, but I'm pretty sure that was what led to the other hub failing.

content: First of all, if you have a macbook pro this will not work for two screens. I am speaking for my macbook pro 2019 I am not sure if theres a different result on older models. If you hook up two or more monitors to this thing the monitors will have the same exact screen. They can't work as their own. I had one hooked up to the hdmi and the other two the vga. Second, this docking station gets very hot. I have had to hook up two of them because I had another one I was going to sell once I got this one, but since this one doesn't work for dual external monitors I had to keep it in order to use both monitors separately. Finally and most important, it blew out the usb-c port it was connected to. I then googled what to do and was told by many forums to try and do a simple "sms reset" which could possibly fix the port, but instead it blew out my batter and destroyed my logic board aka "mother board" and I lost my data and had to take it in to be repaired. I have to believe that my port going out and then this happening to my batter/logic board were connected because an smc reset is harmless. My macbook pro 2019 was only 3 months old.  I am only giving this two stars because you if you can remember to unplug and or not let it run all day every day it might not end up happening with the same result. But it gets very hot very quickly so if you can find another docking station that fits your needs I highly recommend getting that one.

author: silentbob343
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2019
content: I don't typically write rviews, but I thought this could provide useful to those looking at this item with a Dell XPS13 7390 2-in-1.Two observations:1.  When plugging in the XPS13 powersupply, factory, and then plugging the hub in to the laptop I was greeted with a message at startup letting me know that the charging device detected would not be able to power the laptop entirely on its own and would require battery usage.2.  High pitched noise coming from the the hub when the Dell XPS13 powersupply was plugged in.  This noise sounds like a coil whine, but is most likely some type of ground loop issue.Both of these issues could be a product of the Dell's power supply, but in either case it does not seem to be a good match for the XPS13 7390 2-in-1.  While writing this review I realized I only tried this product with one outlet and perhaps should try additonal outlets in my home to make sure that wasn't part of the issue.  I will try it in additional outlets and update the review with those results.  If I experience the same behavior it will be going back.

content: Update: customer service reached out and refunded the full amount.  In addition, they inquired if there were any other remedies they could offer to make things right. Therefore I am updating my review as the product works well but buyers should be aware of the issue that occurs when the computer sleeps as noted previously.Been using this for over a month as a dock for a laptop to connect to dual displays with the lid closed. I quickly realized that every time the computer went to sleep while not in use, when I brought it back online the 2 displays would no longer extend, only duplicate the same thing on both screens. When I pointed out the original cost, they asked me to return it and they would send a refund.  I proposed they send a new unit and I would return the defective one when it was received. Then they replied that it wasn't actually defective, but that the product does in fact have to be unplugged each time the computer goes into sleep mode so it is working "properly".  If that's true it should have been noted in the description because who wants to unplug everything and plug it back in every time you walk away for a while? I adjusted my power settings somewhat as a workaround but don't want to leave the computer running 24/7 so it is still a problem I have to deal with. Not happy with this product and will be looking for something else that works like common sense would dictate.

author: Brian B
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 20, 2020
content: I bought this "hub" in order to "dock" my Lenovo t480 laptop and support 2 HDMI monitors for my "work at home" setup. I shopped very carefully before selecting this unit, and double checked that it supported the features I wanted. The enclosure body is aluminum and feels smooth and solid. The "dongle" is long enough. To this hub, I've connected 2 HDMI monitors, a wired network connection, and 2 USB cables to the 2 monitors where each monitor has a USB 2.0 Hub. My laptop charger plugs directly into the hub. There are still extra USB 3.0 ports and SD slots available. When I "dock" my laptop, I just plug this USB hub into my laptop's USB-C port ... and I'm done. The laptop uses the USB-C data connection to connect to the wired internet, the HDMI monitors, and the various USB peripherals. The hub powers the laptop and charges the battery.A couple of notes. The first time I plugged things together the laptop complained about not having all the power it expected , but after a few seconds the issue cleared and hasn't returned. I don't know if it was a delay negotiating to a more powerful power-delivery setting, or it the laptop charger was not keeping up with demand. The laptop power supply is only rated for 65w, Just in case, I've separately ordered a 100-watt PD charger and cable that I expect to use when I'm "docked".A couple reviews suggest the hub might get quite hot during use. That hasn't been an issue for me. In my setup, the hub has good circulation and is only warm to the touch when it is running.

content: I purchased the UtechSmart Triple Display UDB docking station to enable me to work from home more efficiently.  My setup is two HP 24f 23.8" IPS LED FSH Freesync monitors, a Dell Latitude 7480 laptop and a Logictech wireless keyboard and mouse.  I also purchased a 87W USB C power adapter so that I would only have one plug (from the docking station) going into the laptop. After talking to UtechSmart support, they quickly sent me a new docking station and now everything works perfectly.
